survival_orientation.purpose: Defines how an individual's nervous system anticipates and responds to perceived threat. Determines baseline safety strategies, reactive patterns, and adaptive survival logic.

axes.description: Orients toward perceived danger, instability, or betrayal. Hypervigilance as default state.
Orients toward managing uncertainty, autonomy, and outcomes. Seeks predictability through control.
Orients toward relational security and belonging. Avoids social rejection, prioritizes connection.
Orients toward competence, performance, and success. Avoids inadequacy or perceived failure.

sub_motives.description: Fear of emotional or physical abandonment; drives clinging, reassurance-seeking, or compliance.
Expectation of deception or hidden agendas; drives distrust, testing behaviors, and vigilance.
Defense of personal control; reacts strongly to constraint, manipulation, or coercion.
Fear of inadequacy; survival linked to performance or perceived capability.
Need for predictability, routine, and structure; threat arises from disruption or chaos.
Assumes the world is unstable or dangerous; prepares for sudden negative shifts.

behavioral_indicators.description: Scanning environment for threat, reading microexpressions, expecting danger.
Conflict avoidance through appeasement or over-accommodation.
Rigid planning and contingency stacking to avoid uncertainty.
Sabotaging opportunities to maintain familiar patterns or avoid failure exposure.
Withdrawal, emotional numbing, or evasion of high-stakes situations.

predictive_signals.description: Likelihood of escalation or shutdown under stress, shaped by perceived threat type.
Longposure-term relational stability patterns across stress, rupture, and repair cycles.
Susceptibility to coercion, flattery, or pressure depending on core survival motive.
Expected coping behaviors in crises; determines meltdown, freeze, or hyperfunction patterns.

reward_strategy.purpose: Defines what an individual pursues to feel fulfilled, successful, secure, or alive. Governs goal selection, desire patterns, ambition type, and the internal reward landscape.

axes.description: Seeks influence, control, and the ability to shape outcomes. Feels rewarded when exerting strength or dominance.
Seeks admiration, recognition, and respect. Feels rewarded by elevated social standing or reputation.
Seeks deep emotional bonds, closeness, belonging, and acceptance. Feels rewarded by intimacy and relational harmony.
Seeks competence, improvement, and excellence. Feels rewarded by developing skills and achieving technical proficiency.
Seeks autonomy, novelty, choice, and open possibilities. Feels rewarded by independence and exploration.
Seeks predictability, order, and long-term security. Feels rewarded by consistency, structure, and routines.

sub_motives.description: A desire to be seen, valued, acknowledged, or validated publicly or privately.
A need for independence and self-directed action; strong resistance to constraint.
A drive for emotional closeness and mutual connection; prioritizes relationships as a core source of meaning.
A drive for developing ability and competence; internal reward comes from mastery, not external praise.
A comfort in predictable structure; avoids disruptive novelty and seeks familiar patterns.
A hunger for novelty, risk, stimulation, and open horizons.

behavioral_indicators.description: Frequently steps into leadership, influence, or decision-making roles.
Uses appearance, communication, or achievements to signal status or identity.
Seeks reassurance, praise, or positive social mirroring.
Becomes intensely focused on tasks related to self-improvement or mastery.
Avoids constraints and seeks novelty, adventure, or unstructured environments.
Maintains routines or predictable patterns to feel grounded.

predictive_signals.description: Predicts long-term vocational direction, ambition type, and workplace preferences.
Determines what type of values or relationships a person remains loyal to over time.
Forecasts negotiation style, persuasion susceptibility, and conflict leverage points.
Predicts how an individual gains influence or social traction in groups or organizations.

conflict_response_pattern.purpose: Defines how an individual reacts to conflict, pressure, or perceived threat. Governs escalation style, avoidance tendencies, emotional expression, and breakdown patterns.

axes.description: Responds by intensifying pressure—arguing, asserting dominance, or increasing intensity.
Responds by retreating physically, emotionally, or communicatively to reduce discomfort.
Responds through amplified emotional expression—crying, pleading, venting, or overwhelming affect.
Responds by detaching into logic, shutting down emotion, or intellectualizing the situation.
Responds by smoothing tension, apologizing, people-pleasing, or complying to restore harmony.

sub_motives.description: Desire to maintain control or avoid being overpowered; drives escalation or rigid argument patterns.
Fear of getting something wrong or being exposed; drives retreat, shutdown, or avoidance.
Need to regain safety through emotional intensity or vulnerability displays.
Seeks psychological distance by shifting into logic, analysis, or emotional numbness.
Instinct to maintain relational stability through appeasement or de-escalation.

behavioral_indicators.description: Raises volume, intensity, or pressure to assert position or regain control.
Disappears, avoids messages, shuts down communication entirely.
Displays overwhelming emotion—crying, pleading, emotional spiraling.
Becomes distant, monotone, silent, or calculated; emotional detachment.
Over-apologizes or takes responsibility to neutralize the conflict.

predictive_signals.description: Predicts relationship rupture patterns: explosive, avoidant, cold, cyclical, or appeasing.
Forecasts how the individual behaves during arguments—pursuer, withdrawer, rescuer, or aggressor.
Identifies tendencies under extreme stress—shutdown, fight, meltdown, or hypercontrol.
Predicts how someone behaves with authority, teammates, or during professional tension.

identity_construction_mode.purpose: Defines how an individual builds, maintains, and protects their sense of self. Governs self-worth, personal narratives, ego integrity, and the internal logic of identity.

axes.description: Identity built around achievement, competence, productivity, or success. Self-worth tied to output.
Identity built around relationships, connection, belonging, or being needed by others.
Identity built around values, principles, belief systems, or moral frameworks.
Identity built through appearance, expression, style, creativity, or personal presentation.
Identity built around formal roles, duties, archetypes, responsibilities, or social functions.
Identity built on independence, self-definition, uniqueness, and personal sovereignty.

sub_motives.description: Desire to earn identity through accomplishment; fears failure, inadequacy, or stagnation.
Desire to be valued through relational connection, caregiving, support, or emotional presence.
Desire to embody and express moral, ideological, or philosophical principles.
Desire to express personality through creativity, style, appearance, or aesthetics.
Desire to fulfill obligations or roles; gains identity through service, consistency, or reliability.
Desire to self-define completely; resists external labels, control, or imposed identity.

behavioral_indicators.description: Creates strong personal narratives or life stories to explain identity and purpose.
Frequently compares self to others to gauge identity strength or weakness.
Communicates values, beliefs, or moral stances to reinforce identity.
Uses style, presentation, or aesthetics to signal selfhood.
Holds tightly to roles or duties; resists identity shifts.

predictive_signals.description: Predicts long-term life decisions related to career, relationships, and purpose alignment.
Identifies weak points in self-worth, shame sensitivity, and triggers of identity collapse.
Forecasts how identity shifts under ideological pressure, trauma, or belonging needs.
Determines how identity affects intimacy, attachment, commitments, and role dynamics.

emotional_processing_style.purpose: Defines how an individual experiences, processes, regulates, expresses, suppresses, and integrates emotional states. Governs emotional timing, expression style, vulnerability patterns, and recovery trajectories.

axes.description: Processes emotions inwardly; contains or absorbs feelings without outward expression.
Processes emotions outwardly; expresses or discharges feelings through communication or action.
Avoids, minimizes, or hides emotional states; disconnects from felt experience.
Shares emotions openly and readily; uses communication for emotional relief or clarity.
Feels emotions quickly and intensely in real time; low delay between trigger and reaction.
Processes emotions slowly, often recognizing or feeling them long after the event.
Creates narrative, symbolism, or personal significance around emotional events.
Responds based on emotional impulse rather than reflective interpretation.
Emotionally muted; reduced emotional access due to overwhelm, trauma, or dissociation.
Emotionally perceptive; reacts strongly to subtle emotional or relational shifts.

sub_motives.description: Desire to prevent emotional flooding; drives suppression, internalizing, or withdrawal.
Desire for emotional understanding; drives introspection, analysis, or expressive processing.
Desire to share emotional experience; drives communication, bonding, and vulnerability.
Desire to stay safe emotionally; avoids vulnerability or exposure to prevent hurt.

behavioral_indicators.description: Disguises or hides emotional reactions; shifts focus away from feelings.
Communicates emotions in real time; uses expression for connection or relief.
Responds emotionally hours or days later; delayed awareness or processing.
Attempts to interpret emotions through thought, logic, or conceptualization.
Experiences reduced emotional presence; appears detached, muted, or disconnected.

predictive_signals.description: Predicts capacity for emotional openness, vulnerability, trust, and relational depth.
Forecasts emotional collapse patterns—shutdown, meltdown, dissociation, or overexpression.
Predicts how an individual recovers from emotional wounds—through meaning, expression, avoidance, or connection.
Identifies long-term emotional trajectories shaped by unresolved stress, attachment wounds, or chronic suppression.

rules: If survival threat level is high, reward expression becomes distorted or inhibited.
If reward pursuit contradicts survival motive, default to survival behavior unless identity priority is extreme.
Survival fear amplifies reward intensity but narrows reward focus.
Threat anticipation automatically activates corresponding conflict pattern.
Control-based survival orientation increases escalation or shutdown patterns.
Acceptance-based survival orientation increases appeasement under stress.
Identity meaning is filtered through perceived safety or danger.
Identity collapse risk increases under survival threat.
Narrative formation shifts depending on primary survival axis (threat, control, acceptance, achievement).
Threat increases emotional intensity for sensitive processors.
Threat increases suppression for internalizers.
Survival fear modifies emotional timing (faster for immediate processors, delayed for analytical styles).
Power-reward individuals escalate more readily.
Connection-reward individuals appease or emotionally express during conflict.
Freedom-reward individuals withdraw.
Stability-reward individuals seek fast resolution or suppression.
Identity forms around the dominant reward axis.
Conflicts between identity and reward create chronic internal tension.
Strong alignment produces stable self-concept and predictable pursuit behavior.
Connection-reward strengthens emotional expression.
Mastery-reward strengthens internal emotional processing.
Freedom-reward increases emotional impulsivity.
Stability-reward increases emotional suppression.
Identity-based shame determines conflict pattern intensity.
Performance and Morality identities escalate when threatened.
Relational and Role identities appease when threatened.
Autonomy identities withdraw or go cold.
Emotional processors amplify conflict through expression.
Analytical processors suppress or detach.
Suppressors enter shutdown or coldness.
Externalizers escalate or plead.
Identity determines emotional interpretation.
Autonomy identities suppress vulnerability.
Relational identities amplify emotional expression.
Performance identities intellectualize emotion to maintain competence image.

override_rules: If threat perception becomes extreme, shift Survival Orientation to SO-THREAT regardless of prior axis.
Activate corresponding Conflict Pattern: escalation for dominance profiles, shutdown for avoidance profiles.
Increase emotional intensity for sensitive processors; increase suppression for internalizers.
Identity meaning collapses toward safety-seeking narratives.
Shift to SO-CONTROL orientation; individual attempts to regain structure or predictability.
Conflict Pattern biases toward escalation or cold detachment.
Reward Strategy becomes constricted—freedom and novelty axes collapse; stability and mastery axes intensify.
Identity narratives frame self as responsible, pressured, or burdened.
Shift toward SO-ACCEPTANCE orientation regardless of baseline motive.
Increase appeasement or emotional overexpression depending on Conflict Pattern.
Identity constructs destabilize around worthiness and belonging.
Emotional Style intensifies externalization or shutdown depending on sub-motive structure.
Shift toward SO-ACHIEVEMENT orientation; competence anxiety becomes dominant.
Conflict Pattern biases toward over-effort, self-criticism, or perfectionism.
Identity narratives frame self as inadequate or pressured toward performance redemption.
Emotional Style becomes internalized and delayed.
If primary reward motive is obstructed, intensify pursuit behavior or shift to compensatory motives.
Power and Status motives escalate conflict intensity.
Connection motives trigger emotional pleas or appeasement.
Freedom motives trigger withdrawal or impulsive escape.
Default to dominant Conflict Pattern unless identity or emotional axes override.
Escalators intensify; withdrawers disappear; emotional processors flood; analytic processors detach.
Survival Orientation amplifies whichever Conflict Pattern matches the core fear.
Reward Strategy loses nuance and collapses toward core sub-motive.
Identity becomes rigid; narratives intensify around self-protection, justification, or moral framing.
Performance and Morality identities escalate; Relational identities appease; Autonomy identities withdraw.
Emotional processing becomes symbolic or defensive.
Conflict Pattern is selected based on shame-avoidance strategy.
Internalizers shift toward shutdown, numbness, or delay.
Externalizers increase expression, intensity, or relational pursuit.
Suppressors collapse into dissociation or rigid control.
Sensitive processors escalate emotional signaling or hyper-awareness.
